headline: CNN Live Event/Special
subHeadline: First Lady On Biden 2024 Reelection Bid: "I'm All For It"; Jill Biden On Haley's Call For Mental Competency Tests: "Ridiculous"; Jill Biden: Jimmy Carter's Legacy Will Be As A "Great Humanitarian". Aired 9-10p ET

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON COOPER, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Senator Lindsey Graham is going to join us, as well as DEA Administrator, Anne Milgram.An important conversation, I hope you join us, for it. It's tomorrow night, at 9 PM Eastern, right after 360. The CNN PRIMETIME Special JILL BIDEN ABROAD starts now. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Tonight, Jill Biden takes the world stage. Her first trip to Africa, as first lady.JILL BIDEN, FIRST LADY OF THE UNITED STATES, JOE BIDEN'S WIFE: The young people of Namibia are not only our future, but our present.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: She'll answer tough questions on the biggest issues back home.

utterances.speaker: ARLETTE SAENZ, CNN WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: What do you say to those people, who say maybe he's too old to be president?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: While serving as an important voice, for the Biden administration, abroad.

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: You are the keepers of democracy.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Dr. Biden speaks about her mission, and the challenges, facing the continent.

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Everybody has to come together, to make sure that these people aren't dying, because of the drought.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And her inspirational reunion with a woman she first met more than 10 years ago.

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I said, you could go anywhere, be anything. And you said, "No, I'm staying in my community."

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Plus, her family's decision, on President Biden's run, in 2024. SAENZ

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: CNN PRIMETIME, JILL BIDEN ABROAD, starts now.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: SARA SIDNER, CNN SENIOR NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Good evening. I am Sara Sidner.Tonight, on CNN PRIMETIME, an in-depth interview, with the first lady of the United States, a one-on-one with Jill Biden, who returned, from a five-day trip to Africa. CNN was in Africa, alongside the first lady, as she toured through Namibia and Kenya, seeking to raise awareness, about the severe drought and hunger crisis, in the Horn of Africa, championing the role of women, in democracy, and so much more. We have exclusive footage to show you, along with a fascinating, wide- ranging conversation, with our own Arlette Saenz, who asked Dr. Biden, some of the most pressing questions, many Americans have, about 2024. They delve into the discussion, about the President's age, and those classified documents found on Biden's properties. Our Audie Cornish, and Abby Phillip, are here, to discuss the news, from this interview. But first, Arlette is with us, with her incredibly strong reporting. You asked a lot of questions, and she seemed to answer candidly?

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Yes. There were really no topics that were off-limits. And we were able to speak with the first lady, about a host of issues, relating to Africa.But first, we also got her thoughts, on things, like 2024, and whether he'll seek reelection, those questions about his age, as well as her thoughts, on some of the former first ladies. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: So, we are here, in Africa. But there are a host of issues and decisions waiting for you--

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Waiting, just waiting.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: --back home. Maybe the biggest is this decision and announcement about a 2024 campaign.

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Your husband was asked in an interview, if he was running. And he joked that he had to call you, to find out.

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Was this recently?

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: It was recently.

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Oh! I must have missed it.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: So, we're going to the source!

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Where do things stand? When's an announcement coming?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Well, he said he intends to run. So, nothing's been planned yet. I think he's been so busy with being in Ukraine, handling some of the crises at home. So, I think, he's now -- he's putting that first. He's putting America's business before he's putting his own.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: But has the decision been made amongst the family that he's going to run?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: It's Joe's decision. And we support whatever he wants to do. If he's in? We're there. If he wants to do something else? We're there too.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Is there any chance, at this point that he's not going to run?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Not in my book.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: You're all for it?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I'm all for it, of course. There's so many things that he's done, brought people together, brought leaders together.And so, he says, and I think you heard him, say at the State of the Union, "I'm not yet finished. I'm not yet finished." And so, I see his vision. And I hope Americans see his vision as well.

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I say, "Look at what he's done. Look at what he's doing." Look at how physically he's got the good bill of health from the doctors, to his physicals. But how many 30-year-olds could travel to Poland, get on the train, go nine more hours, go to Ukraine, meet with President Zelenskyy?(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: VOLODYMYR ZELENSKYY, PRESIDENT OF UKRAINE
utterances.sentences: Good morning, Mr. President.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.sentences: Good morning (ph).(END VIDEO CLIP) JILL BIDEN: His energy level, his level of passion. So, look at the man. Look what he's doing. Look what he continues to do, each and every day, and make your decision. It's up to the American people.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Nikki Haley, one of the Republican candidates, is calling for mental competency tests, for those politicians, over the age of 75. What do you think about that?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: It's ridiculous.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Would your husband ever take one of those?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I mean, we haven't even discussed -- we would never even discuss something like that.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: You talked a little bit about your husband, traveling to Ukraine, and Poland, this past week.

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: You also have told us that you found out kind of last minute that he was going to make this--

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Oh, absolutely.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: --secret trip, to Ukraine.

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: What was it like, for those 10 hours, when he was taking that train ride, into Ukraine, and no one knew? How worried were you, in those moments?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I was of course worried. I mean, I was really worried.But one thing? And I have to say this, with all my heart. One thing that I truly believe in is the strength of our military, and how everything was so planned out, and the Secret Service, and what an amazing job, they did, in pulling off the trip, and keeping my husband safe. I mean, I'm watching the TV, this morning. And I'm seeing, it's just incredible, what's going on in the air and in the sea. And I hope that Americans really take note of it. Like we have to give the support, all of our support, to our military, because of what a great job they do. And the Secret Service is right there hand-in-hand.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Were you able to keep tabs on him when he was--

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: How do -- did you communicate?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Well through texts.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Through texts? JILL BIDEN

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Was he texting you on the train?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Well, he was -- no, he wasn't texting me on the train. But it was in the back of my mind. And so, I mean, I was kind of aware that he was safe. And I just said a lot of prayers.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Did he give you a call when he made it back into Poland?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes, yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: And what was his reflection on this clandestine trip?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: We didn't -- it wasn't -- we didn't really talk about it. I think it'll be just better to talk about it in private, you know? Yes.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Have you had the chance to talk to him about this trip yet?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes. We've spoken a couple times, and FaceTimed. And so, yes. And he looks great. I mean, so he doesn't look tired, or -- yes.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: How often do you guys FaceTime?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I don't know, couple times a day.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Even if you're just in D.C.?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Oh, sure.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Or when you're traveling?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Well I'm -- yes, I'm traveling. I'm at work.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I mean, he calls like he calls a lot.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Does he call you more? Or do you call him more?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I think he calls me more.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: I want to turn to another issue that has come up, amongst Republicans, a lot. And your son, Hunter, has really been a target, for Republicans, over the years, and likely will be, in the years to come. How does your family deal with that intense focus, on Hunter?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: We deal with it by just, I guess, have a different perspective. I mean, I love Hunter, and I'll support him, in any way I can. And that's how I look at things.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Has the wave of investigations, into him, does that factor into any of the thinking, heading into 2024?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: The Justice Department has appointed the Special Counsel, to look into the way that your husband handled classified documents, when he left the Vice Presidency.

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: When did you first find out about these documents? Were you surprised?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Probably when the rest of America did. I was really surprised. We had no idea. And so, I think we found out when everybody else did.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Where in the house were they? Were they in a secure location? Did people have access to them?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Well, I think they were at the Biden Penn Center.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: And there were some at your home, in Wilmington, as well?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Yes. And I think those were in the garage. And believe me, Arlette, I am not, I haven't even -- I mean, I don't have time to go through, the boxes in the garage. And we had no idea they were even down there.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: I wanted to turn back to one campaign question.

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Oh!

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: You and I--

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: You're not giving up!

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Oh no, I'm not!

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: See?

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: But I guess--

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: You're saying "Everybody's asking you." There you go, Arlette.

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I think every campaign is grueling. I don't care whether you're 20, 30 or whatever age. Campaigns now have become really grueling. And Arlette, you've been on a lot of campaigns. You have to see the difference between even 10 years ago, and today.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: I know you guys are really big into these family meetings.

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Was there one definitive family meeting that "OK, we're doing this?" Or has this been a rolling conversation?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: It's been rolling, this time. Last time, we did have a family meeting. And we've had family meetings other times. But it's sort of rolling, just because of the pace of our lives. And so, if I can grab two grandkids, here, and say, "Hey, what are you thinking about? What are your thoughts?" Or, our daughter? So, I'm sort of keeping tabs.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: So, in your mind, this is happening?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.You want to come? You want to come on the trail?

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: I might be -- I might be covering you guys on the trail again.

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Oh, good, good.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: We are back now, with Arlette.We're also joined, luckily, by Audie Cornish, and Abby Phillip. Arlette, I'm going to start with you. So, you asked all of the questions that I think the American public has been discussing, about Joe Biden. And then, you get into what Jill Biden has been up to. Were you surprised by any of her answers?

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: I think that her answer, regarding 2024, is quite interesting. I think the way that she answered that question, really makes it seem as if it's not a matter and if -- of if, but when this campaign will be launched.But she also does leave an opening for him, should he decide not to run in 2024. She says, it's Joe's decision, that they'll support him if he does. And then, she says, "But if he decides to do something else, we'll also support him there." So, it kind of provides you a little bit of answer, both ways. But, these conversations that I had with her, over the course of those five days, in Africa, it really does seem like things are moving towards him running for reelection again, in the coming months.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I do want to ask about this controversy, I don't know if that's what to call it, but over age. It's come up again and again. And Nikki Haley pushed it to a whole another level when she talked about a competency test. Jill Biden responded with, "It's ridiculous."Audie, what do you make of her response to that? AUDIE CORNISH, CNN ANCHOR AND CORRESPONDENT, CNN HOST, "THE ASSIGNMENT WITH AUDIE CORNISH" PODCAST: I mean, first of all, I think she's more surefooted, in general, in terms of how she approaches the press, and talks to the press. She's been in this game, for a very long time. It's a little bit different from first lady, Michelle Obama, who married someone, who was not in public life, when they first got together. Jill Biden has been in this for a while. But it also underscores the problem for them. Here they are, she's on a trip, visiting countries, in Africa. The posture that this administration has had towards Africa is radically different than the prior administration. But it's a conversation that can't be had. Because not only are people focused on whether he's going to run, but even being able to ask the question, should he at all, because of his age. I mean, that really, I think, gives you a sense of the kind of obstacles for them.

utterances.speaker: ABBY PHILLIP, CNN SENIOR POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT, CNN ANCHOR, INSIDE POLITICS SUNDAY
utterances.sentences: It also struck me that she was answering the question over and over again, at every chance that she got, even when Arlette wasn't asking her about it.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: She's talking--

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Like she was ready with an answer.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, she's talking about the Ukraine trip. She's talking about his stamina, his ability, to do all of that. I mean, I think she is keenly aware that this is an unavoidable question, about her husband. And she is injecting it every moment, and opportunity, to say, "This is a guy, who can keep up. This is a guy, who has what it takes, who's all there."And, I mean, to Audie's point, Jill Biden, is perhaps one of the most prepared women to ever be first lady, because of how long that she has been Joe Biden's wife. And I didn't really see any doubt in her in this interview. I think she thinks her husband can do it. And she's kind of wondering why we keep asking her about it. And that really, I think, tells you everything that you need to know. She would probably be the first to say, "It's time for us to take a step back." And that's not a woman who wants to take a step back.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: I think she made that really clear. I do want to ask you guys about classified documents.She said something that struck me, "We found out when the rest of the country did." And when she says, "We," I mean, is it plausible that they had no idea that they were there?

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: I think it's certainly plausible that they didn't know that they were there. I'm not sure about both of them finding out, when the rest of the country did. But yes, it is possible that they didn't know that they were there. I mean, this is a former Vice President of the United States. He's not going through old files in his--

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: At the same time, the issue has been somewhat neutralized by Mike Pence, also having documents.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Obviously, the Trump ongoing investigation, I think, for the public, at this point, it's like, everyone's got a box, they should figure this out.And it's really about waiting for the Justice Department, to see if there's anything sort of more nefarious, to your point, though anything related to Hunter, anything that can be connected to him in some way. Expect to hear more of that in any forthcoming kind of congressional hearing, especially led by House Republicans.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: And we should also be clear that, Joe Biden did not hold on to these, after he learned that they were there. And there is a difference between him--

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: --and Trump.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Like he's not under investigating--

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: --for obstructing, in any way.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: CORNISH
utterances.sentences: Or not cooperating, which is very different from the former President.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Yes, same goes for Pence.Arlette, Audie, and Abby, are staying right here with us, because there's just so much more ahead. Up next, why being first lady is harder than Jill Biden ever imagined, and whether she's heard, from her predecessor, which is customary? (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Most of the first ladies, "If you ever need anything, or you want to talk, or if there's something on your mind, or if I can help you in some way?" They've all been great.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Have you spoken with Melania Trump?(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Welcome back to CNN PRIMETIME.Arlette Saenz's in-depth interview, with the first lady, while she was in Africa, "First lady Jill Biden goes abroad" continues right now. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: You've said that being first lady is a bit harder than you had imagined. Which parts of it are more difficult that you thought maybe would have been?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Well, the schedule, I mean, that's one part of it. So with the, being a mom, and a grandmom, and a wife, I mean, you have to fulfill those roles. And then, you layer on first lady, and you layer on teacher.So, like you're saying, just trying to balance it all, is, you have to be very organized, which I think all teachers are. But I just think you have to find balance. And that's what every day, I strive to find balance.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: I know, you've said that you are not the President's adviser. You're his spouse. But you do hold a lot of influence. And I'm sure, over the years, you have learned, when to weigh in, and when not to.

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: So, what are the areas you do offer him advice on?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Well, certainly, I tell him stories, and of things that I've seen, and things that people want, and where their challenges are. So, it's not that I'm like weighing in. It's like, "Let me tell you, what I saw or what I heard, or what people are saying to me." And so, it's in that context.Because, I'm out every day, I'm in the classroom. I'm out, somewhere in the United States. And so, I think it's a good balance, really.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: And I think there's a lot of focus, on the role, and the impact that you have, on him. But how does he help you?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Well, sometimes, I don't -- I may not see things, from his perspective. Let's just put it that way. And so, he offers both sides. I'm always a little bit better, like, "This person feels this way."He's very good at that, understanding why people feel the way they do. He understands both sides, which is part of his strength, I think, that he can, work with people, as he's done, Arlette, on both sides of the aisle. He may not agree with them. But he does understand their perspective.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Are there areas where the two of you just agree to disagree?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: What are they?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I don't think I want to get into it. I don't want to create another argument at home!

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: I want to ask you about Jimmy Carter. What do you think Jimmy Carter will ultimately be remembered for?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I think he'll be remembered as a great humanitarian. I mean, all that he has done to help people? He never stopped. He never stopped, helping Americans, whether it was Habitat for Humanity, building homes, or going into communities, traveling the world, helping people all over. And I actually feel a little sad, even saying this, because he's still with us, thank God. And -- but I think that will be his legacy.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: I mean, you and your husband visited him, and Rosalynn Carter, at their home in Plains, Georgia.

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: I think it was in 2021. Can you talk to us a little bit about what that moment was like, your interactions with them then?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Well, he and Joe get along so well, and have so much in common. And, I mean, they talked politics, the whole time, and what was going on. And they have a real ease in -- with one another. You've seen it. And they do so much together.And she's so much a part of his life. I don't know. I worry about her.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: In what way?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Well, what will she do? They've been married, what, over 70 years? It's a really strong partnership. SAENZ

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: No, I don't think I have. She's always been very supportive. As have, quite frankly, most of the first ladies. "If you ever need anything, or you want to talk, or if there's something on your mind, or if I can help you in some way?" They've all been great.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Have you spoken with Melania Trump?

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Not Melania.

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Oh, sure, absolutely. And I don't care whether they're Republican or Democrat. I think it's a big role. I think, if they ask, I mean, I'm not going to, but if they ask? Of course. I mean it's a very small number, at this point of women, and I think we have to support one another.(END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: The first lady's passion to highlight women, supporting women, goes well beyond the United States.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN
utterances.sentences: So, we can look to Namibia and say, "Look, it's working there. It's going to work for us as well."(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: How Jill Biden is finding inspiration, half a world away, when our CNN PRIMETIME Special continues.(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: For first lady, Jill Biden, the opportunities that come with a ceremonial role, in the White House, are about far more than photo ops. And when she visits Africa, she is no stranger to that.Arlette Saenz is back with us, to look at the personal connections she's nurtured, and the hope that she sees even as parts of the African continent struggles.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Yes. And she really was trying to take some of her key messages that she has here, in the U.S., over to Africa as well. And she's spent there -- as time there, as second lady, and that really has given her some familiarity, with the continent, as she tried to spread her messages, from both Namibia to Kenya.(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) SAENZ (voice-over): Dr. Jill Biden, in Africa, for the first time, as first lady. A return to a continent that's familiar to her. She traveled to Africa, five times, as second lady. But in her debut trip, as first lady, Biden kicks things off, in Namibia.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: (FOREIGN LANGUAGE).SAENZ (voice-over): A young country, where preserving democracy was at the top of her mind.

utterances.speaker: JILL BIDEN, FIRST LADY OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: You are the keepers of democracy.

utterances.speaker: CROWD MEMBER
utterances.sentences: Amen

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Amen, that's right amen.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: She says the relationships she's built as first lady drew to her to the country.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: We had the Africa U.S. summit in December, and I met Monica, the spouse of the president of Namibia, and we just hit it off so fast and she said, you know, come to my country.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Why is it important to you to build these types of relationships with other first ladies?

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Because I think the one thing Joe taught me is that all politics is personal, and that -- that's true, because once you have these connections, you can call on someone when you need help, when you need to be lifted up, when you can support programs.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Throughout her five-day trip, she pushed for women to use their voices, and for young people to get involved, using her own experience as an educator for more than 30 years to connect with locals.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: And what subject do you want to teach?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: English.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Do you have a favorite author?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yeah, Shakespeare

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Shakespeare! Wow.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: And with her granddaughter Naomi in tow offered simple gestures to children.On the flight from Namibia to Kenya, no time for a break. Dr. Biden still teaches full time back home, juggling her work as first lady, focusing on helping military families and working to end cancer. SAENZ:  How do you spend this time on the flights in between countries?

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Reading. You see these books, I spend my time reading, grading papers and I'm a reader. I'm an English teacher.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Biden is carrying on a long tradition of first ladies visiting Africa, starting with Patricia Nixon in 1972, continuing from Hillary Clinton to Melania Trump.Laura Bush touted her husband's PEPFAR program to fight HIV/AIDS.

utterances.speaker: LAURA BUSH, FORMER FIRST LADY
utterances.sentences: Well, it does seem like an insurmountable problem, but the fact is you can measure progress.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: And Michelle Obama urged countries to educate young girls

utterances.speaker: MICHELLE OBAMA, FORMER FIRST LADY
utterances.sentences: These are young women transforming their communities and their countries

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: On the ground in Kenya, Biden promoted economic empowerment for women with the country's first lady, and met with young people on the importance of safe sex.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: So, besides condoms, does it promote birth control pills?

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: On Biden's final day in Kenya, we drove about three hours south of Nairobi, over bumpy dirt roads to the rural village of Lositeti, part of the Horn of Africa suffering through severe drought.Nearly 500 people gathered there to receive medical checkups and nutritional assistance, the first lady talking with members of the Maasai community, whose livelihoods are threatened and mothers struggling to feed their children.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: All their livestock are dying.  As we came down that long road of the livestock and how they're just skin and bones. And so they're left with nothing.  Some of the women told me that they're walking three hours a day, to go into a populated area. So they really need a lot of help.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: What more needs to be done?

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Everybody has to come together to make sure that these people aren't dying, because of the drought. Because, believe me Arlette, they have nothing. They have nothing and their children are malnourished, and they're receiving, you know, from USAID these food supplements. And but that's not enough, that's not a meal. It's a supplement.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Having visited the same drought plagued region in 2011, when she toured the country's largest refugee camp, it's an issue she's passionate about.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: We're right on the edge, we're right on the precipice, I think of a famine, where, which is what I saw thousands of refugees coming from Somalia, walking miles and miles with children, who were sick and trying to carry them. And the children were so weak, we're right on the edge. We need to act now.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: The U.S. announced it's sending more than $126 million in additional food assistance to Kenya. But the first lady pushing for more countries to pitch in aid, while also hoping her visit offered the community a simpler message.

utterances.speaker: SARA SIDNER, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: And more from Arlette's in-depth interview ahead, including the message the first lady says she is bringing to Africa after former President Trump used derogatory language to refer to some African nations.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: We want to say, hey, we're back.(END VIDEO CLIP) (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Welcome back.Two years after the Trump presidency, First Lady Jill Biden went to Africa with a message from the United States. Here's more of CNN's interview. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: You are here in Africa, paving the way for other White House officials to come. Vice President Harris is expected to come, your husband President Biden has committed to visiting this year. When you go home, what is the main takeaway you share with him from this trip?

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Well, I think we'll talk about democracy, certainly. Furthering democracy, and as we talked about Namibia, as a young democracy, and then to come here to Kenya, just to say to our global partners, we're standing with you.I saw certainly, you know, women's empowerment here, I saw youth groups, what the American programs are doing, and that people are responding to them the youth, which is so important here, as you know, 75 percent of the population is under 30, which is amazing in itself. [21:40:13] SAENZ:  What kind of impact do you think a visit by a first lady has compared to a president's visit?

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I hope it has a major impact. I think it just creates awareness of a lot of programs that we support.And so, I think it does have an impact. And I think I take that back. And I can incorporate that in my speeches. And when I'm going around our country and talking about really the price of freedom and democracy.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Do you think there are connections that you're able to make as first lady that perhaps the president can't?

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Well, I think as a teacher, myself, I think maybe those, I feel that those connections are a little stronger. Joe tends toward policy as he should, and I try to, you know, go in a little bit, maybe a softer direction.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: We've talked about how Africa has a large youth population, it's home to some of the fastest growing economies in the world, and a lot of countries are trying to make inroads here, including China. Do you feel at all that the U.S. is losing influence in Africa?

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Well, I don't know whether they're losing interest. But I can't speak to that. But I can speak to America's interests. And so, America wants to keep reassuring the countries and the leaders of Africa, like we didn't forget you. You know, we were isolationist, pretty much for the last four years of the last administration.And I think countries around the world, I mean, whether it was NATO, whether it was you know, Mexico, Canada, I mean, all these alliances that we formed, Latin America, they were wondering, like, hey, America, what happened to you? You know, we used to be partners, we used to strive towards the same things. Not that we all agreed on everything, but certainly, there was a dialogue, and then it's sort of like America, you know, stepped away, like, no, we don't want to deal with every other country. And so, we want to say, hey, we're back.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Why do you think it's hard for Americans sometimes to pay attention to what's happening here in Africa?

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: You know, the one thing I find about Americans, and this is what I found the last time when I came here, in 2011, well, this is how I got here. I was watching TV, and I saw these children dying. And I was shocked, like, you know, that people that were so many countries have so much food, and yet people are dying.And right then, I called my chief of staff and I said, we've got to do something about this. We've got to create awareness. And, and we did I mean, I think within three days, we were on an airplane, we came, we created awareness, Americans responded, they opened their hearts, to see people, children, just skin and bones and, and they're responded with their pocketbooks. And so, sometimes they need a little nudge, like, hey, I know things are tough, maybe in your household or your, you know, this is a bad month, but hey, look at what somebody else is dealing with.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: You talked a little bit about your way to connect with people here as an educator, after all these experiences with these young people, young adults, what do you take back to your classroom to share with them?

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: You know, I have so many students from other countries, that I learn more about their countries, you know, that I don't think I take much back to them, I think they give me so much.You know, one of my students, I texted her yesterday on the one-year anniversary of Ukraine, the war in Ukraine. And I said, I hope you're ok. You know, how's your family? How are you doing? And she said, hey, Dr. B, you know, how about can I come in and have lunch with you on Tuesday, so she'll come. And so, that's the sort of connections you know, I have, I'm telling you, Arlette, I have a lot of freedom fighters from a lot of different countries who come to the United States to get their education. And sometimes you just wonder, my goodness, how did you get here with all the violence that you've seen, all the war that you've been through? I mean, I've learned so much really from them. (END VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Arlette, Audie and Abby are back with us.After hearing her remarks on Africa, I'm curious from you if there's something that really -- she tried to make a really big point here about the difference between the two administrations, the former and her husband's administration.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Audie and Abby, the Chinese -- and this is -- you know, people have been watching what China is doing in the African continent and what Russia is doing partly because of what's happening in the world globally, but the Chinese have traded with Africa about four times as much compared to the United States.Is this -- I'll start with you, Abby. Is this something that the U.S. is catching up on their relationship with Africa because of this, or are we reading that wrong?

utterances.speaker: ABBY PHILLIP, CNN SENIOR POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, it's a really important question. I actually a few weeks ago spoke with the U.N. Ambassador Linda Thomas-Greenfield, and she said to me she views China and Russia as catching up to the United States in terms of the relationships that the United States has had with multiple countries on the continent and especially in sub-Saharan Africa over decades. What that means at this moment is that for China, catching up means really investing quite a lot in this moment in Africa.And when you talk about the food crisis, you talk about oil, Russia is such a huge player in that, and the United States is aware of that, they are trying to counter that. And as Arlette was just saying, they're keenly aware that they believe in the four years of the Trump administration, there was time lost.

utterances.speaker: AUDIE CORNISH, CNN CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: You'll notice the language from the second lady but also Tony Blinken is partnership. Hi, we're still here. Hi, we still want to be involved in what's going on here.So I think that it's this idea of reengagement in the world and that may mean the continent of Africa. That also means maintaining support in Ukraine, but it's trying to kind of reassert the U.S., our position to ourselves about what is our role internationally.

utterances.speaker: SIDNER
utterances.sentences: Two role models living thousands of miles apart reunite in Nairobi, Kenya, years after forming a special bond. Our cameras were rolling and CNN's Arlette Saenz was there to see when First Lady Jill, Biden have this reunion and you join us again, Arlette.This is quite touching, isn't it? SAENZ:  Yeah, it really was a special moment between these two women, a first lady of the United States and a woman that she had met 13 years prior. She visited Kenya, a moment, a visit that the first lady has described as something that really changed her life. And we were there as the two women caught up with each other on each other's lives. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Oh my goodness. Hello!SAENZ (voice-over):  It was a reunion more than ten years in the making. Aliyah (ph), a mom of two, lives in Kibera, an informal housing settlement in Nairobi.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: So how are your children?

utterances.speaker: ALIYAH
utterances.sentences: My children, they're doing well. Actually, you met Jamal.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: He was four.

utterances.speaker: ALIYAH
utterances.sentences: Yeah, he was too small. But now I have Salma. Salma is two years, and doing well.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Dr. Jill Biden first met Aliyah during a trip to Kenya in 2010 when she was second lady, and the two immediately shared a bond.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: This woman, Aliyah, is one of the young women who's a role model for many of the other young women and we talked about living in the slum. And when I said to her, Aliyah, are you working to try to get out of the slum? And she said, oh, no, I'll live here my whole life. This is my community.Remember I said you're so smart, you could go anywhere, be anything. And you said no, I'm staying in my community.

utterances.speaker: ALIYAH
utterances.sentences: Yeah, yeah, yeah.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I remember that so well.

utterances.speaker: ALIYAH
utterances.sentences: I wanted to fight for them.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: True to her word, she's still there, and still fighting.

utterances.speaker: ALIYAH
utterances.sentences: I'm a single mom, but I feel grateful because every each and every day, I fight for them. And that's why I would like Salma to get a good education that I didn't get it. Because I wish to go far, to go to university, to go anywhere.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: Aliyah became a business owner, opening a restaurant in Kibera. She was forced to close during the COVID-19 pandemic, but she recently received a grant to reopen.

utterances.speaker: ALIYAH
utterances.sentences: They are willing to support me reopen my business. And I think to this, it will be a great opportunity because I've been wishing for the best for the young girls of Kibera and for me, it will be like a great opportunity for them.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: During the 13 years apart, Aliyah also kept tabs on the first lady.

utterances.speaker: ALIYAH
utterances.sentences: So how is your family back home?

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: My family's good. It's been a journey and since I last saw you because that's when husband was as vice president, and now, he's president.

utterances.speaker: ALIYAH
utterances.sentences: By the way, congratulations.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: ALIYAH
utterances.sentences: Actually, when everything was happening, I was like one of the voters down here, I was like yeah, good people, good people, I need good people. So I felt so much grateful.This is Salma.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Salma?

utterances.speaker: ALIYAH
utterances.sentences: Salma.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: How are you?

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Oh, my gosh, I loved her. You know, when I met her, she was such a beacon of hope.She had a little four-year-old son, and she was running a program to teach young women about violence and domestic violence and how to protect themselves against rape, and she was so impressive. And then to see her again, 10 years later. And now, of course, her son's 18. And, and she has a new daughter, two years old. And, and she's still at it. She's still working for her community. And I think it's such a strong message that people try to, you know, help their own communities.

utterances.speaker: SAENZ
utterances.sentences: The two women hoping this meeting won't be their last.

utterances.speaker: ALIYAH
utterances.sentences: I'll never forget you in my entire life because I was so much super excited to meet you again and thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: And, you know, fate brought us together, right?

utterances.speaker: ALIYAH
utterances.sentences: Yeah, sure, sure.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: ALIYAH
utterances.sentences: And I hope one day, maybe I'll have time to visit America.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.sentences: I hope so.

utterances.speaker: ALIYAH
utterances.sentences: See how America, how you are doing over there. Yeah, hopefully.(END VIDEOTAPE)
